comments:
Build: I20070220-1330

FormsResources creates three cursors that are never disposed. As far as I can see, the dispose method on this class is never called.  Minimally they should be disposed when the plugin shuts down, or even better, disposed when there are no form widgets in existence.

Sample sleak trace:

java.lang.Error
	at java.lang.Throwable.<init>(Throwable.java:58)
	at org.eclipse.swt.graphics.Device.new_Object(Device.java:786)
	at org.eclipse.swt.graphics.Cursor.<init>(Cursor.java:230)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.forms.widgets.FormsResources.getHandCursor(FormsResources.java:38)
	at org.eclipse.ui.forms.widgets.AbstractHyperlink.<init>(AbstractHyperlink.java:120)
	at org.eclipse.ui.forms.widgets.Hyperlink.<init>(Hyperlink.java:50)
	at org.eclipse.ui.forms.widgets.FormToolkit.createHyperlink(FormToolkit.java:354)
	at org.eclipse.team.internal.ui.mapping.DiffTreeChangesSection.createEnableParticipantModelProvidersPane(DiffTreeChangesSection.java:320)
	at org.eclipse.team.internal.ui.mapping.DiffTreeChangesSection.getEmptyChangesComposite(DiffTreeChangesSection.java:231)
	at org.eclipse.team.internal.ui.mapping.DiffTreeChangesSection$8.run(DiffTreeChangesSection.java:495)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.RunnableLock.run(RunnableLock.java:35)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Synchronizer.runAsyncMessages(Synchronizer.java:123)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runAsyncMessages(Display.java:3484)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:3124)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java:2286)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runUI(Workbench.java:2250)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.access$4(Workbench.java:2125)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench$4.run(Workbench.java:459)
	at org.eclipse.core.databinding.observable.Realm.runWithDefault(Realm.java:289)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.createAndRunWorkbench(Workbench.java:454)
	at org.eclipse.ui.PlatformUI.createAndRunWorkbench(PlatformUI.java:149)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.ide.application.IDEApplication.start(IDEApplication.java:101)
	at org.eclipse.equinox.internal.app.EclipseAppHandle.run(EclipseAppHandle.java:146)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.runApplication(EclipseAppLauncher.java:106)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.start(EclipseAppLauncher.java:76)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:354)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:169)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:85)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:58)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:60)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:391)
	at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.invokeFramework(Main.java:476)
	at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:416)
	at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:1124)
	at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:1099)

I can either:

1. Match the lifecycle to FormToolkit. This means cursors for every toolkit, but won't linger in memory.
2. Dispose on bundle deactivation. Fewer resources, but they linger in memory.
3. Invent some new fancy approach to resource management (e.g. reference-counting toolkits). Good on resources but complicated.

Any preference Dejan?

These three cursors are created once per Eclipse instance. Although they stay around, I don't think this should be our highest priority right now. They are created when the first UI Forms client loads this class and will never create any more cursors.
Note that if there is a place to get these three cursors elsewhere, we would gladly take them from there.
